articles.headline: A New Genre on Wall St.: Bailout Blog
articles.snippet: The blog of a Bear Stearns executive offers insights into the investment bank’s response to the near collapse of two hedge funds.
articles.abstract: The blog of a Bear Stearns executive offers insights into the investment bank’s response to the near collapse of two hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the weekend of June 17, executives at Bear Stearns scrambled to avert the collapse of two hedge funds.

articles.headline: Often-Asked iPhone Questions
articles.snippet: Just how much of a phone, an iPod and an Internet machine is this thing?
articles.abstract: Just how much of a phone, an iPod and an Internet machine is this thing?
articles.lead_paragraph: With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.

articles.headline: New Commitment to Charity by Mexican Phone Tycoon
articles.snippet: Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where millions live in poverty, that distinction has been drawing heat.
articles.abstract: Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where millions live in poverty, that distinction has been drawing heat.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, June 27 — Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat.

articles.headline: Asia’s Long Road to Recovery
articles.snippet: The financial crisis that rocked Asia a decade ago is past, but in the countries most affected, a sense of loss persists.
articles.abstract: The financial crisis that rocked Asia a decade ago is past, but in the countries most affected, a sense of loss persists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, June 23 — As the founder of a petrochemicals business empire that aggressively expanded in refining, plastics, steel and cement, Prachai Leophairatana once ranked among Asia’s wealthiest men.

articles.headline: Food-Safety Crackdown in China
articles.snippet: Chinese regulators closed 180 food plants after a nationwide inspection found thousands of violations of food safety rules.
articles.abstract: Chinese regulators closed 180 food plants after a nationwide inspection found thousands of violations of food safety rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, June 27 — After weeks of insisting that food here is largely safe, regulators in China said Tuesday that they had recently closed 180 food plants and that inspectors had uncovered more than 23,000 food safety violations.

articles.headline: Wider Sale Is Seen for Toothpaste Tainted in China
articles.snippet: Roughly 900,000 tubes containing a poison have turned up in hospitals and prisons, according to health officials.
articles.abstract: Roughly 900,000 tubes containing a poison have turned up in hospitals and prisons, according to health officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: After federal health officials discovered last month that tainted Chinese toothpaste had entered the United States, they warned that it would most likely be found in discount stores.

articles.headline: In West Bank, Hamas Is Silent but Never Ignored
articles.snippet: Hamas, shrewd as it is deadly, has gone to ground in the West Bank, but it remains a powerful presence there.
articles.abstract: Hamas, shrewd as it is deadly, has gone to ground in the West Bank, but it remains a powerful presence there.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAWARA, West Bank, June 26 — A new code was born here overnight. No one, it seems, belongs to Hamas in the West Bank anymore. Everyone now is an “Islamist,” a word that neatly, and maybe more safely, shears the religious from party affiliation amid the uncertainty of a Palestinian people newly divided.
